data.title: Unknown crash not being picked up in debugger
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7, Godot 2.0.3 stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When clicking a treasure card control after selecting a player, the game crashes.
It's supposed to assign the card to the player.

**Steps to reproduce:**
(This will include a brief tutorial on the game)
Select a room to place
Place a room on a treasure node (go for green for now, otherwise you'll die horribly)
Combat begins
Click a card, then click an enemy to use the card on them
Defeat all enemies
The game will now enter the treasure reward state
Click a player, then click the treasure card
The game will crash, in a way not picked up by the debugger

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
Cannot reproduce in minimal example project, but here's a link to my project.
https://bitbucket.org/nosrick/monquest

EDIT:
It turns out the editor actually catches some sort of error, which is attached.
![cusersjamesdesktopgodot_v2 0 3_stable_win64 e_2016-06-28_17-29-15](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1487089/16423948/fd9100b4-3d55-11e6-8efe-5e0a241f6514.png)

data.title: a method to know if a joystick is plugged
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Official 2.0.3stable and custom 2.1alpha

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

I've found no method to know if a joystick is already plugged.

The workarounds are : 
- scan device from 0 to 15 using `Input.is_joy_known()` ; but, if I understood correctly, it will only return true if the joystick has a mapping.
- ask the player to press a button and capture the device number in event.

I would like to know in advance how many joysticks are already connected without asking to the players to press buttons.

**Steps to reproduce:**

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Input.is_joy_known() and joy_connection_changed signal are confused when plugging and unplugging mixed Xinput and DirectInput joysticks
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

Tested on official 2.0.3stable win64, and on custom 2.1alpha compiled by @calinou few days ago. 
Running under Windows 8.1 64.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

`I'M HAVING TROUBLE EXPLAINING THIS ISSUE CLEARLY AND SIMPLY`
_so please, in case my description appears confusing, follow the step by step guide below to reproduce the issue and read the minimal example project script to have a better understanding of what i'm talking about._

Before running the project, you have a USB Xinput controller (like XBOX360 gamepad) and a USB DirectInput controller (like Thrustmaster dual analog 3) that are connected at the same time.

When you run the project, the Xinput controller will have device number 0, and the DirectInput controller will have device number 1.

Still at runtime, if you unplug the DirectInput controller, the signal callback `joy_connection_changed` will receive a device number 0 instead of 1, and `Input.is_joy_known(0)` will return false instead of true, and `Input.is_joy_know(1)` will return true instead of false.

When you connect theDirectInput controler again, `joy_connection_changed` will receive a device number 1 (which is correct), but `Input.is_joy_known(0)` will still return false instead of true.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Using the minimal example project, follow this step by step guide.

1) BEFORE RUNNING THE PROJECT, plug an USB Xinput controller (like Xbox 360 controller) and a DirectInput USB controller (like a Thrustmaster dual analog 3).

2) run the example project.

3) you should read :
- "joy 0 : XInput Gamepad"
- "joy 1 : Thrustmaster Dual Analog 3.2"
- "joy 2 :" should be grayed
- "joy 3 :" should be grayed

4) press your controllers buttons to verify their device number as returned to _Input(event).
- XInput controller device number should be 0.
- DirectInput controller should be 1.

5) unplug the DirectInput controller.

6) You'll notice that "joy 0 : XInput Gamepad" will vanish instead of "joy1", and that the signal callback joy_connection_changed() will receive device_id 0 instead of 1.

7) press your Xinput controller buttons to verify its device number. 
It still should be 0.

8) plug the DirectInput controller back, and notice that this time the signal callback joy_connection_changed() will receive device_id 1.

9) unplug and replug the DirectInput controller and see that the device_id is 0 when unplugging, and 1 when replugging.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

https://github.com/SuperUserNameMan/godot_issue_minimal_example/tree/master/input_is_joy_known

data.title: Corrected a typo
Add Android export option for manifest chunk injection
data.body:
I have to put the chunks of the manifest in folders of the modules and sometimes I have to change a code for each game (for example: GooglePlayGameServicesAPI), sometimes the chunks are duplicated and I have to delete one (for example: AdMob and GooglePlayGameServicesAPI), so:
- Is a good thing to make as a export option?
- Is in the roadmap of the GodotEngine something like this, or some system for add android modules as plugins or something similar in the near future?

In case that I'm in the good way, I already started this feature adding parameter to the export dialog, and now I am fighting with the injection into the manifest of the APK.

data.title: Get Better Collada Exporter into Blender upstream
data.body:
[This thread](https://developer.blender.org/D1787) shows many blocking issues that prevent the Blender team from merging BCE. Can't those issues be easily fixed? 

Additionally, the last comment says that the Blender team is working on a Python-based Collada importer to replace OpenCollada for 2.8. Maybe the efforts can be joined and/or parts of BCE can be integrated into their new exporter?

I say this because if the Blender community maintained it, it would get a lot of features in a short time.

data.title: Current GDScript function detection for coloring is quite poor
data.body:
It seems to only color names that have a `(` just afterwards without any spaces. So `my_func()` is highlighted, but `my_func ()` is not. It is the same with function declarations and signals (which IMO could have a different color, even if the default were equal to the function color).

Maybe the color guy @Paulb23 want to look at this.

```
def get_opts():
...

...

...

                env.Append(LINKFLAGS=['-framework', 'GameKit'])

        if env["store_kit"] == "yes":
                env.Append(CPPFLAGS=['-DSTOREKIT_ENABLED'])
                env.Append(LINKFLAGS=['-framework', 'StoreKit'])

```

PS.
Why include TOOLS?


data.title: Showcase page: Suggestions for improvements
data.body:
We now have a new page on the website to showcase Godot games: https://godotengine.org/showcase

This issue is meant to gather community feedback on how to improve its functionalities further.

To request the addition of new entries, please contact us directly per email [as mentioned in the blog post](http://godotengine.org/article/showcase-your-godot-game-our-website).

data.title: Make it more obvious which script is being edited
data.body:
Right now it can be quite confusing when the script editor is opened and there's no obvious way to tell which script is being edited. I know that the sidepanel shows the opened scripts and colors them depending on usage(?), but it quickly becomes a headache to find the opened file when there are like 20 opened files and all are red.

That's why I suggest to show the focused script name in the window/application title, when the "script view" is active. Currently it only shows the scene name, but imo it would be better if it distinguishes between the active view ("2D/3D/Script") and adjusts the title accordingly.

data.title: Input event doesn't emitted when mouse pos is within control node
Improve parallax mirroring algorithm
data.body:
Replaces the iterative approach currently used by an equivalent direct computation.
Also fixes infinite looping that happens when the mirroring value is negative.

It's a corrected version of #5391. Tested with the 2D platformer example, Jetpaca and my own project.

data.title: [RPMLint] Error: Program returns random data in a function
Fix compiling for X11 on non-86, this fixes #5444
data.body: This will fix #5444 by checking platform architecture and only set x86 gcc enabled when machine is really a x86 machine.

data.title: X11 Build is broken on non-x86 architectures
data.body:
Trying to compile godot 2.0.3 with x11 is broken on non-x86 architectures like PowerPC64 in my case (using openSUSE).

The reason is: godot the tries to use x86 assembly which will fail on non-x86.

data.title: Add support to String type in gdscript iteration
data.body:
Closes #5188.

My test script:

``` python
extends Node2D

# member variables here, example:
# var a=2
# var b="textvar"

func _ready():
    # Called every time the node is added to the scene.
    # Initialization here
    var x = "abc"
    var y = x[0]
    print("---")
    print(y)
    print("---")
    for c in x:
        print(c)
    print("---")
    for d in "":
        print("shouldn't enter here!")
    pass
```

Output:

```
** Debug Process Started **
[...]

---
a

---
a

b
c


---
** Debug Process Stopped **
```

data.title: Suggestion: "Add Node" and "Classes Reference" dialogs improvement
data.body:
Hello!
It's not an issue, but just a suggestion. The hierarchy in both Add Node and Classes dialogs are fine, but they have some problems of readability like some items having icons, and others not. The fact that some items don't have icons makes the alignment in the hierarchy pretty messy. Example:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19820741/16365667/86b6a44a-3bdd-11e6-994e-ffd52f20d8bf.png)

I suggest four alternatives to this:

1: Removing icons (not a good idea, but at least it's said).
2: Put the icons in the right side of the words (making the words be aligned).
3: Making the items that don't have icons inherit one from the last parent that haves a icon (making the icons be aligned).
4: Adding a reference guideline in each level of hierarchy, making easier to read, like this:

![example_grid_reference](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19820741/16365660/581f44ca-3bdd-11e6-830b-c2d9b8f59208.png)

Also, when the same dialogs are open, the tree is expanded by default, and sometimes is convenient to search category through category. Since there's a lot of items to scroll, and collapse one by one would be inefficient, a button to toggle expand/collapse all items in hierarchy (including the inner items) would be awesome.

I hope you consider this possibilities, that will surely make the interface cleaner.

data.title: [Feature Request] CanvasLayerTexture || CanvasItemMaskedTexture
data.body:
When working with 2D Shaders sometimes you need a sample ob objects in the screen, but not all of them, for example when working with reflections: not all object will be reflectible.
Right now the only way to do the work is using different viewports for every layer and use a ViewportSprite to render them on screen, this is an unconfortable workflow, since the user has to take into acount of game resolution, scrolling and everything itself, and also make sure your objects belongs to the same viewport.

Some solutions i have thought of are:
- Use a CanvasLayer to get a rendered texture
- Have a CanvasItemMask property on viewports, this would allow to have many viewports share the same world and render specific masks. Another option would be to use a CanvasLayer mask, but since CanvasLayers are indexed instead of masked, i can't think in a way to have a proper way to define the layers other than an IntArray with would not be so straightforward.

data.title: [RPMLint] A lot of warings when compiling code on openSUSE
data.body:
Compiling Godot 2.0.3 on openSUSE Tumbleweed (gcc6).

I get following warnings when comping godot:

1 - Undefined behavior of statements:

```
I: Program causes undefined operation
   (likely same variable used twice and post/pre incremented in the same expression).
   e.g. x = x++; Split it in two operations.
W: godot sequence-point scene/animation/tween_interpolaters.cpp:260, 265, 271, 288, 293, 299, 367, 373, 375
W: godot sequence-point scene/gui/line_edit.cpp:455, 459
```

An example is:

```
return c * (t /= d) * t * t + b;
```

What I think should result in:

```
return c * (t / d) ^ 3 + b;
```

But I think it is also possible the compiler interprets it as:

```
return c * t * t * (t / d) + b;
```

2 - strict-aliasing warnings:

```
 I: Program is likely to break with new gcc. Try -fno-strict-aliasing.
 W: godot strict-aliasing-punning ./core/variant.h:464, 469
 W: godot strict-aliasing-punning core/command_queue_mt.h:480
 W: godot strict-aliasing-punning core/variant.cpp:754, 762, 767, 777, 782, 796, 813, 823, 831, 841, 846, 853, 858, 863, 868, 873, 878, 883, 918, 923, 928, 933, 938, 982, 990, 995, 1005, 1010, 1024, 1041, 1051, 1059, 1069, 1074, 1081, 1086, 1091, 1096, 1101, 1106, 1111, 1125, 1126, 1127, 1128, 1129, 1130, 1139, 1178, 1188, 1192, 1197, 1209, 1214, 1219, 1224, 1229, 1234, 1239, 1493, 1517, 1533, 1658, 1660, 1668, 1677, 1685, 1703, 1713, 1731, 1758, 1777, 1796, 1844, 1886, 1894, 1901, 1909, 1918, 1927, 1936, 1946, 2661, 2667, 2668, 2672, 2673, 2674, 2675, 2691, 2692, 2693, 2697, 2698, 2699, 2700, 2723, 2724, 2725, 2726, 2761, 2762, 2763, 2764, 2774, 2782, 2791, 2797, 2803, 2812, 2821, 2831, 2844, 2859, 2875, 2962, 2963
 W: godot strict-aliasing-punning core/variant.h:464, 469
 W: godot strict-aliasing-punning core/variant_call.cpp:49, 216, 212, 220, 228, 384, 392, 400, 407, 210, 214, 218
 W: godot strict-aliasing-punning core/variant_op.cpp:47, 59, 61, 117, 118, 127, 179, 180, 498, 499, 205, 206, 106, 107, 142, 143, 144, 145, 582, 594, 598, 610, 627, 136, 1420, 2274, 3458, 3464, 3526, 3527, 3564, 3565, 3566, 3569, 3573
 W: godot strict-aliasing-punning drivers/etc1/rg_etc1.cpp:2014, 2015
 W: godot strict-aliasing-punning drivers/unix/ip_unix.cpp:161
```

3 - Gethostbyname

```
I: binary-or-shlib-calls-gethostbyname /usr/bin/godot
 The binary calls gethostbyname(). Please port the code to use getaddrinfo().
```

Gethostbyname should not be used because it does not support IPv6, and in v6 becomes more and more popular (e.g. my provider only gives me an IPv6 range and IPv4 only as carrier grade nat).

**EDIT:** Regarding the sequence-point error: It seems godot is compiled without specific -std=c++XXX so it will use c++98 on gcc < 6, which will result in undefined behavior (execution order undefined), but starting with gcc6 c++14 is the default c++ flavor so the Sequenced Before/After is used. Which may result in defined behavior (I am not sure at the moment), so in that case builds with gcc < 6 might be broken.

data.title: Fix visual server error when minimizing the window
data.body:
Fix #4821.
Fix #1930.

~~I'm not sure if this is the right way to fix~~, but it seems that `OS` reports the width and height as zero when minimized and this stops the framebuffer of being properly updated. With this check the errors about the `VisualServer` and `RasterizerGLES2` are gone.

EDIT: I changed my original commit, so now it has the proper way to fix.
